Ignatius

The news about Eluana Englaro filled Italian newspapers.
 Eluana Englaro - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
 
 I think that everyone should decide of its life, in case of serious, painful illnesses or in case of a coma.
 
 
 
 As far as I remember, in the U.S. Terri Schiavo was a similar case.
 
 What do American people think about D.N.R. option?
 Can the Government (or Parliament) decide whether this option can be chosen, or not?

post_info.post_title: Do we have the right do die?

Charliegone
No! The government should stay the heck out of everyone's life. That includes wanting to die for the purpose of sparing a person a painful death.
DrNo
I believe people have the right to die.
CUNxTime
That is a right we don't have absolutely, but absolutely should have.
Charliegone

Don't get me wrong I think they should have the right to die if they are already dying or will suffer a great disability. I don't think they have the right to die if they are just "unhappy" with their life.
peteratwar

Even if a person has the right to die, they have no RIGHT to ask anyone else to help.
 
 The possibility of less than pure reasons that could be used is obvious
Penfold
Why not? The person asked has the right to refuse.
Zardoz

You see Penfold dead at my feet...
 
 
 
 "He asked me to kill him."
 
 How do we know he asked you to kill him?
 
 "Cause I was there when he said it. Why would I lie?"
 
 Where is Penfold's money that was in his wallet?
 
 "It's in mine...cause he gave it to me also."
 
 Any other evidence to support your story?
 
 "Yeah, this note by Penfold asking me to kill him."
 
 It look like your own handwritting.
 
 "Well, yeah. It is. Penfold couldn't write it."
 
 Why not? Was he too ill to move his own hand?
 
 "Nah, He was tied up."
 
 Why was he tied up?
 
 "Cause it makes it easier to kill him like that."
 
 Okay. I guess your story makes sense.
 
 "Good, Now, I got to go visit that despondant teen down the streets. She wants to die too. But, not before loosing her virginity."
 
 And you know this how?
 
 "I'm telepathic..."
 
 emoticon_xbouncer
snakespit
Not only is is our absolute right to die, it is our responsibility.
CUNxTime

Not only is is our absolute right to die, it is our responsibility.

 
 Its the only thing we REALLY have to do!
Zardoz

Its the only thing we REALLY have to do!

 
 Well...I won't comment on how I deal with my texes...
 
 But, since I haven't died yet, I have no reason to believe that I ever will.
 Being dead is for chumps...and people who pay texes.
 
 Yeah, you heard it here, I'm gonna live for ever!
Penfold
Dying is one thing nobody can stop you doing whether you want them to or not.
ibelieveyou

 Eluana Englaro - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
 
 I think that everyone should decide of its life, in case of serious, painful illnesses or in case of a coma.
 
 
 
 As far as I remember, in the U.S. Terri Schiavo was a similar case.
 
 What do American people think about D.N.R. option?
 Can the Government (or Parliament) decide whether this option can be chosen, or not?

 
 Of course posing this question reminds us of the pathetic state of affairs where 'our rights' are a thing determined / manufactured by people other than ourselves. The fact most of humanity remains enslaved to totalitarian governments of varying degrees, who get to choose how [and when] the individual lives, shits and dies is altogether pathetic.
pappillion001

The news about Eluana Englaro filled Italian newspapers.
 Eluana Englaro - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
 
 I think that everyone should decide of its life, in case of serious, painful illnesses or in case of a coma.
 
 
 
 As far as I remember, in the U.S. Terri Schiavo was a similar case.
 
 What do American people think about D.N.R. option?
 Can the Government (or Parliament) decide whether this option can be chosen, or not?

 
 We have the right to die. For a number of reasons we have extremely restricted the right to kill. Zardoz has pointed out some of the more obvious reasons why this is so. 
 
 If a person chooses to end their life as long as their is no purposeful coercion in making that choice and practical arraignments made, it should be left to the individual.
 
 I think most Americans share this view, but its the fear of the potential abuse of any type of legislation that allowed the termination of life that prevents government from enacting it.
pappillion001

Of course posing this question reminds us of the pathetic state of affairs where 'our rights' are a thing determined / manufactured by people other than ourselves. The fact most of humanity remains enslaved to totalitarian governments of varying degrees, who get to choose how [and when] the individual lives, shits and dies is altogether pathetic.

 
 What good is a right if no one respects it. 
 
 Your right to life means squat after someone violates it. Government serves the purpose of protecting your rights. It does this when a group gets together and they agree what will be a right they will protect and what won't be and what will violate a right. 
 
 Your alternative is to wander the jungle subject to the whims of any individual or group who can impose their will on you and your only recourse is what you are capable of producing.
ibelieveyou

Your alternative is to wander the jungle subject to the whims of any individual or group who can impose their will on you and your only recourse is what you are capable of producing.

 
 Exactly! And what hope of "recourse" does an individual stand againt predacious ubiquitous government in the concrete jungle?
 
 Government merely replaced clergyism and feudalism. Government "protects our [manufactured] rights" as a swineheard protects the rights of his swine as his contains them in a pen of swill and muck.
gansao

Exactly! And what hope of "recourse" does an individual stand againt predacious ubiquitous government in the concrete jungle?
 
 Government merely replaced clergyism and feudalism. Government "protects our [manufactured] rights" as a swineheard protects the rights of his swine as his contains them in a pen of swill and muck.

 
 Exactly.Our 'rights' and 'freedom' is limited by what is allowed by more powerful people than us
pappillion001

Exactly! And what hope of "recourse" does an individual stand againt predacious ubiquitous government in the concrete jungle?

 
 What freedoms have been unreasonably denied you? What rights that you posses that you may not seek recourse?
 
 
 Government merely replaced clergyism and feudalism. Government "protects our [manufactured] rights" as a swineheard protects the rights of his swine as his contains them in a pen of swill and muck.[/QUOTE]
 
 All rights are manufactured. A wild animal cares nothing for your right to your life or property. If you were the only person on earth would the concept of rights exist? Would they have any meaningful value? 
 
 History has given us plenty of examples of how people respect what we consider rights without some form of force or consequence to maintain them. It's like you think the social order that exists is caused by the goodwill of man towards each other and that government is an unnecessary infringement on something you are entitled to.
pappillion001

Exactly.Our 'rights' and 'freedom' is limited by what is allowed by more powerful people than us

 
 Such as? Can you give an example or two of rights or freedoms that are being unreasonably limited without reason?
gansao

Such as? Can you give an example or two of rights or freedoms that are being unreasonably limited without reason?

 
 I never said that your freedom was unreasonably limited.I said your freedom was limited to what more powerful people than you will allow you to have.
 Read the post pappyemoticon_idea
pappillion001

I never said that your freedom was unreasonably limited.I said your freedom was limited to what more powerful people than you will allow you to have.

 Ok emoticon_rolleyes
 
 Who are those people who are more powerful than you limiting your rights and freedoms?
 
 Why do they do this to you?
 
 Are you ok with that? Which ones would you like to be unlimited?
gansao

Ok emoticon_rolleyes
 
 Who are those people who are more powerful than you limiting your rights and freedoms?
 
 Why do they do this to you?
 
 Are you ok with that? Which ones would you like to be unlimited?

 okemoticon_rolleyes
 
 People who make the law,people who influence the people who make the law,people who interpret the law.
 They set the perameters to your freedom and rights.
 Your 'rights' and' freedoms' are what they want them to be not necessarily what you want them to be..therefore they are not necessarily rights or freedoms are they?
 I am ok with that to a point but in the UK at least I think they are unfair to some .
 I never said they should be unlimited.

ibelieveyou

All rights are manufactured. A wild animal cares nothing for your right to your life or property. If you were the only person on earth would the concept of rights exist? Would they have any meaningful value? 
 
 History has given us plenty of examples of how people respect what we consider rights without some form of force or consequence to maintain them. It's like you think the social order that exists is caused by the goodwill of man towards each other and that government is an unnecessary infringement on something you are entitled to.

 
 The notion of manufactured rights is an endless discussion which in any case largely misses the point of social parasitism aka government. Suffice to point out the blinding paradox that the principal culprit in violating "rights" has always been government. All modern wars / conflicts / unconscionable crimes against humanity can be traced to the institution of government or its para equivalent.
 
 So much for glorious government and their gift of rights!
